- `console.log({a: 1})`

It looks like the console is being refreshed constantly, if you can't repro it I can debug some more.

data.title: Website for Visual Studio Code states "Free. Open Source." which is extremely misleading given the download button below is leading to EULA licensed proprietary software. Please don't mislead users intentionally
data.body:
The main landing page https://code.visualstudio.com for Visual Studio Code currently does the following:

1. it states the offered version is "Free. Open Source." which suggests free software to anyone who knows what the difference of "free" and "open-source" in the common word use is

2. Below it immediately offers download buttons  for something licensed under https://code.visualstudio.com/License/ which is **absolutely not free software in any modern definition of the word**.

Therefore, the website's main page is right now *incorrect  and extremely misleading*, since the advertised version on the main page is not "Free." at all as stated prominently.

I am aware the actual licensing page clears this up in a small remark at the top, but anyone just browsing to the main page and thinking about downloading it is almost guaranteed to be misled, and they might even think they got something under a free software license without realizing by downloading they just agreed to a classic non-free EULA which doesn't respect many basic user rights like disassembling and analyzing the software, or providing the software to others as a hosted solution and other non-free restrictions.

Please fix the labeling on the main page and clearly advertise the non-free version on the website as what it is, and stop misleading users.

---
Also, this has been brought up before and you have refused to do so, but I implore you to simply abandon this model entirely. All this confusion and naming mess is just because you insist on twisting a free software into some weird proprietary branded spin-off that doesn't add much except a logo. As you can see, all it leads to is confusion, misleading remarks and even borderline false advertising, which is absolutely not worthy of a company that is clearly trying to embrace open-source and free software and getting rid of their old image from the past.

Please note it is possible to write binding trademark / branding guidelines to allow protected use of a name like "Visual Studio" in a free software product by the community, so you wouldn't need to do this just to be able to brand Visual Studio Code nicely.

Edit:  the full source of that version isn't available either, is it? It is altered from the GitHub variant after all - so the main download is probably not even "Open Source." in a strict definition of the expression, as strongly suggested by the landing page...

data.title: Rename "Code - OSS Dev" to "Visual Studio Code OSS" or something similar
data.body:
Please rename "Code - OSS Dev" to "Visual Studio Code OSS" or something similar. 

The current name is bad (IMHO) for two reasons:
1. The hyphen makes it confusing. As you can see with my edits, I initially thought it was meant to be "OSS Dev"
2. It's not similar enough to "Visual Studio Code". Having the same project named "Visual Studio Code" (branded), "vscode" (OSS repo)", "Code - OSS Dev" (built OSS version), and sometimes just "Code" when talking about it is pretty problematic because people might not realize it is essentially the same program.

This is even more problematic if you consider that the OSS version is already so separate with no official prebuilt packages and the official site has only proprietary EULA branded packages, so making the name so vastly different just makes the situation even more confusing for the user.

Compare for example with Oracle (yes I know they also do bad stuff to OSS, but this is one thing they did right):
- JDK vs OpenJDK
- VirtualBox vs VirtualBox OSE
- ...

If the current naming was done because the "Visual Studio" name is protected, then please have your lawyers write a community use policy of the name so it can be used in the open-source builds too (as "Visual Studio Code OSS" or similar). Other companies managed to do the same, it's not that hard.

Edit: revised ticket to be more clear to read

data.title: Can't run tests under different directory with CLI
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Launching tests within VS Code using the debugger, my tests are run under `./lib/test` as defined in the `launch.json` config file. ([Example](https://github.com/wopian/agc-assembly/blob/a2f43f519442277b05f2fdc9db3f4a5636621440/.vscode/launch.json))

However running tests from CLI, I can't seem to pass the correct tests path.

`npm test` or `node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/test` both attempt and fail to run tests under `reponame/test` by default. Tried passing `--extensionTestsPath=./lib/test` to either of these to no avail.

Terminal Output:
```bash
### VS Code Extension Test Run ###
Current working directory: C:\GitHub\agc-assembly
Running extension tests: C:\GitHub\agc-assembly\.vscode-test\Code C:\GitHub\agc-assembly\test --extensionDevelopmentPath=C:\GitHub\agc-assembly --extensionTestsPath=C:\GitHub\agc-assembly\test


Error: Cannot find module 'C:\GitHub\agc-assembly\test'
```

data.title: Inserting snippets beginning with a placefolder does not select the placefolder text properly.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.0 (38746938a4ab94f2f57d9e1309c51fd6fb37553d, 2016-12-13T17:45:32.595Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.51|

---

- Provide reproducible steps, what the result of the steps was, and what you would have expected.
Steps to Reproduce:

1. input below to \User\snippets\go.json 
```
	"snippet test": {
		"prefix": "prefix",
		"body": "${1:HoldMeTight} = ${2:LoveMeTender}"
	}
```
2. input `Irrésistiblement prefix` to new line on editor.
3. press ctrl+space, then, "prefix" is replaced to "HoldMeTight = LoveMeTender" and "Irrésistibl" (the first few characters of the same line) is selected. selection length is the same as the length of left-most placefolder text.
4. in case of `"${2:~} = ${1:~}"`
    1. at first, $1 text is selected properly.
    2. next  selection after pressing Tab key is "Irrésistibl" (not $2 text)

- A description of what you expect to happen
  - selecting the placefolder text (in case above, selecting "HoldMeTight")
  - if the body of the snippet does not begin with placeholders like `"_${1:HoldMeTight} = ${2:LoveMeTender}"`, the left-most placefolder text is selected properly.
- Errors in the Dev Tools Console (Help | Toggle Developer Tools)
  - nothing is displayed.
- can you reproduce the issue when starting vscode without extensions by using the --disable-extensions command line argument?
  - yes.

data.title: VSCode on Windows 10 + Docker: Wrong build path
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1 (stable)
- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 14393

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Docker for Windows
2. Install VSCode
3. Add Docker extension
4. Create an empty Folder (eg MicroServiceTemplate) and open it in VSCode
5. Generate a Dockerfile from the command palette with default settings
6. Run Docker: Build from the command palette

Here the questions are already filled with the wrong values, like selecting the Dockerfile, it shows `e\Dockerfile` 

The Build fails then with ```C:\Users\max06\OneDrive\Dokumente\Develop\MicroServiceTemplate>docker build -f e\Dockerfile -t e:latest e
unable to prepare context:
unable to evaluate symlinks in context path: GetFileAttributesEx C:\Users\max06\On
eDrive\Dokumente\Develop\MicroServiceTemplate\e: Das System kann die angegebene Da
tei nicht finden.``` 

When I try to build it manually with correct parameters, it works.

data.title: VSCode crashes when building ionic app

Since one of the recent VSCode updates, each time I run Ionic's build command - the VSCode crashes. data.title: Use a more flexible indentation in different files
data.body:
Different language has different indent rule.
Java: always use 4 spaces.
Go: always use a tab with length 4.
Makefile: must use a tab.

But now, when I create a new `Makefile`, the indentation will use previous file rule(4 spaces)?
Always change settings is annoying.
For a high availability, we can add default indent rule for different file type.

data.title: Preserve undo/redo buffer when saving a file "as" or untitled file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Undo last edits.
2. Save As.
3. Try Redo to re-instate last edits, but nothing happens.

This is a workflow I have done in many other editors where I realize I want to keep an old version of something I am working on, just in case I screw up. To my dismay in VSCode it made me lose all my edits.

data.title: Builtin official python support
data.body:
Hi

I just want to ask if there is any plan for the official support for python intellisense? If so is there any expected timeline for it ?

Thanks
